variant.question: You have recently passed your initial training and line check for an operator and it is only your 6th flight as an inexperienced pilot. During the briefing, you realise that the captain youâ€™re scheduled to fly with has also recently passed his/her command upgrade and it is only his/her 3rd flight. Can you fly together?

options.text: No, there are too many inexperienced flight crew.
Yes, as long as the dispatcher is aware and allows it.
Yes, you have passed your supernumerary flights therefore you can fly with an inexperienced captain.
Yes, since both of you have completed your respective training, you count as experienced crew.

variant.question: State the requirement for a differences training:

options.text: Differences training requires the acquisition of additional knowledge and training on an appropriate training device or the aircraft.
Differences training requires the acquisition of additional training on an appropriate training device or the aircraft.
Differences training requires the acquisition of additional knowledge.
Differences training requires the acquisition of additional training on the aircraft.

variant.question: An aeroplane pilot is taking a course of training to upgrade from Co-pilot to Commander.  This command course contains many elements, one of which is to complete....

options.text: line training under supervision, in an aeroplane, for at least 10 flight sectors.
at least 5 hours of training in an FSTD, followed by line training in the aeroplane.
line training under supervision, in an aeroplane, for at least 10 hours, including at least 5 flight sectors.
at least 10 hours training in an FSTD, which includes LOFT training.

variant.question: Why might a pilot be required to follow familiarisation training? - To operate another aircraft of the same type. - To convert to a different class of aircraft. - To operate another version of an aircraft of the same type. - When minor changes of equipment are introduced to the aircraft normally flown.

The holder of a CPL(A) (aeroplane) shall only act as commande<u>r</u> in commercial air transport on a single-pilot aeroplane if either of the following conditions is met, when operating on a multi-engine type under IFR, he/she has a minimum of...

options.text: 700 hours flight time, including 400 hours as pilot-in-command.
700 hours flight time, including 200 hours as pilot-in-command.
400 hours flight time, including 100 hours as pilot-in-command.
200 hours flight time, including instrument time.

variant.question: Differences training requires...

options.text: additional knowledge and training on the aircraft or an appropriate training device.
reinforcing the pilot`s knowledge on types or variants currently operated.
refreshing the pilot`s knowledge on types or variants currently operated.
only the acquisition of additional knowledge.

variant.question: A new pilot joined the airline. He/she has just done the checks, but is flying with a captain who is commencing his/her line check. The new pilot is placed ont the commander seat. What is the role of the new pilot on this flight?

options.text: He/she will be a commander if the operator dedicated him/her to be.
The new pilot is the commander because he/she is on the commanders seat.
The captain commencing the line check is the pilot-in-command for this flight.
Both are commanders for this flight.

variant.question: When can the commander grant access to parts of the aircraft that are unsuitable for the carriage of persons?

options.text: For the purpose of taking action necessary for the safety of the aircraft
For the purpose of required crew rest
At any time when the commander decides
For normal procedures required in completion of  in-flight checks

variant.question: Commanders whose duties require them to operate in either pilot seat and carry out the duties of a co-pilot, or commanders required to conduct training or checking duties, shall complete additional training and checking as specified in the operations manual. The additional training and checking shall include at least the following:

options.text:
An engine failure immediately after take-off,
 a critical engine-failure 400 ft after take-off and
 a one-engine inoperative holding pattern.

An engine failure during take-off and
 a one-engine-inoperative landing.

A take-off, approach and landing without engine failure, and
 an engine failure during take-off,
 a one-engine-inoperative approach and go-around, and
 a one-engine-inoperative landing.

variant.question: An operator with one type of aircraft buys a variant of that type. What do you need to do?

options.text: A differences training with practical training.
A differences training without any practical training.
A familiarization training without any practical training.
A familiarization training with practical training.

variant.question: For a VFR public transport on an aircraft, the flight manual indicates a minimum crew of one pilot. When may the regulations require the presence of a second pilot?

options.text: Never, provided certain conditions are met.
If the flight lasts more than 3 hours.
If part or all the flight is done at night.
Whenever the aircraft is a twin-engine.

variant.question: You are working for a company with 2 airplane and 3 helicopter types, how many are you allowed to fly?

options.text: One airplane and one helicopter.
Only the type on which you have the greatest experience.
Only the type for which the type rating was completed first.
Both airplanes but only one helicopter.

variant.question: If an operator assigns crew members to standby or to any duty at the airport, such operator has to provide for...

options.text: accommodation.
transport to and from the airport.
food and beverage.
entertainment.

variant.question: An aeroplane command course requires a commander to carry out under supervision (PICUS):

options.text: at least 10 sectors.
10 hours and at least 5 sectors.
20 hours and at least 5 sectors.
20 hours and at least 10 sectors.

variant.question: Personnel records about crew member training, checking and qualifications shall be stored for a period of...

options.text: 3 years
The last 2 training records must be kept.
long enough until he/she moved to another company.
7 years

variant.question:
A Pressurised aircraft with two flight crew members is flying at 11000 feet
 The differential pressure of the cabin is zero
 Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: Both flight crew members should use supplemental oxygen, for any period exceeding 30 minutes at this altitude.
At least one flight crew member should continuously use supplemental oxygen until the aircraft descends below 10000 feet.
Both flight crew members should use supplemental oxygen continuously, as the cabin altitude exceeds 10000 feet.
At least one flight crew member should use supplemental oxygen, for any period exceeding 30 minutes at this altitude.

variant.question: Who has the final say if someone is allowed in the cockpit?

options.text: commander
operator
safety manager
flight safety officer

variant.question: When a flight crew member operates both commercial helicopters and aeroplanes, that flight crew member shall be limited to operations on...

options.text: only one type of aeroplane and one type of helicopter.
only three types of aircraft in total, independent if aeroplane or helicopter.
only one type of aeroplane and two types of helicopters.
only two types of aeroplanes and one type of helicopter.

variant.question: How often is recurrent training

options.text: 12 months
6 months
18 months
24 months

variant.question: Who gives final authority for entrance to the flight deck?

options.text: The commander
Senior cabin crew member
The Operations officer
The Operator

variant.question: In accordance with OPS regulations, an operator shall ensure that a pilot does not operate an aeroplane as commander unless

options.text: he has carried out at least 3 take-offs and 3 landings in the previous 90 days as pilot flying in an aeroplane or in a flight simulator of the same type/class.
he has carried out at least 3 flights as commander in the previous 90 days, in an aeroplane or an approved flight simulator of the type to be used.
he has carried out at least 3 take-offs and 3 landings in the previous 60 days, as pilot flying in an aeroplane or an approved flight simulator of the type to be used.
he has carried out at least 3 take-offs and 3 landings in the previous 60 days, as pilot flying in any type of aeroplane or an approved simulator, under the supervision of an examiner.

variant.question: Pilots qualified to fly both fixed wing aircraft and helicopters are limited to:

options.text: One type of aeroplane and one type of helicopter.
Two types of aeroplane and one type of helicopter.
One type of aeroplane and unlimited types of helicopter.
One type of helicopter and unlimited types of aeroplane.

variant.question: Pilots qualified to fly both fixed wing aircraft and helicopters are limited to:

options.text: one type of aeroplane and one type of helicopter
one type of aeroplane and any number of helicopters
one type of aeroplane and two types of helicopter
two types of aeroplane and one type of helicopter

variant.question: How often does recurrent training for Line Checks have to be carried out?

options.text: Every 12 months.
Every 6 months.
At least every 13 months.
As and when required.

variant.question: OPS regulations specify the requirements for an Operator to conduct Initial Crew Resource Management (CRM) training. Which one of the following is authorised to conduct this training?

options.text: A suitably qualified CRM trainer.
A pilot holding a Type Rating Instructor (TRI) qualification.
A Training Captain holding a Type Rating Examiner (TRE) qualification.
A line training captain.

variant.question: According to OPS regulations, a pilot is not assigned to operate an aeroplane as part of the minimum certificated crew, either as pilot flying or pilot non-flying unless he/she has carried out

options.text: 3 take-offs and 3 landings in the previous 90 days, as pilot flying in an aeroplane or in a flight simulator of the same type/class.
3 take-offs and 3 landings on this type of aeroplane during the previous 6 months.
6 take-offs and 6 landings as pilot flying on the same type of aeroplane or approved simulator, of the aeroplane type to be used.
6 take-offs and 6 landings during the previous 6 months.

variant.question:
What additional training must a pilot do in order to take command in either seat?
4 Answers - pick 1

options.text: An engine failure during take-off, a one-engine-inoperative approach and go-around,  a one-engine-inoperative landing.
A take-off, an approach, a landing.
A one-engine-inoperative approach, a one-engine-inoperative landing, a one-engine-inoperative go-around.
A Precision approach, a take-off with engine failure simulated, a landing.

variant.question: In accordance with EASA AIRCREW regulation, including night operations, an operator shall ensure that a pilot does not operate an aeroplane or helicopter as commander unless he has carried out at least:

options.text: 3 take-offs and 3 landings as pilot flying in an aeroplane or helicopter of the same type/class or in a flight simulator of the aircraft type to be used, in the preceding 90 days, and 1 take-off and landing at night.
3 take-offs and 3 landings as pilot flying in an aeroplane or helicopter or an approved flight simulator of the type to be used, in the preceding 30 days, and 1 take-off and landing at night.
3 flights as commander in an aeroplane or helicopter or an approved flight simulator of the type to be used, in the preceding 90 days, including 1 flight at night.

3 take-offs and 3 landings as pilot flying in any type of aeroplane or helicopter or an approved simulator, under the supervision of an examiner, in the preceding 60 days and 3 take-offs and 3 landings at night.

variant.question: Differences training ....

options.text: Additional training and knowledge
Addition knowledge only
Familiarisation
Additional training only

variant.question: What is the purpose of a differences training?

options.text: A differences training is used extend the privileges of a pilots licence to another variant of aircraft within one class or type rating.
A differences training is used extend the privileges of a pilots licence to another variant of aircraft within one class rating only.
A differences training is used extend the privileges of a pilots licence to another variant of aircraft within one type rating only.
A differences training is used extend the privileges of a pilots licence from VFR to IFR.

variant.question: There are several ways for a pilot to comply with the 90-day recency requirements for operating an aeroplane/helicopter at night for commercial air transport. What combinations of recent experience are acceptable, according to the aircrew regulation? - Three take-offs, approaches and landings in an aeroplane/helicopter or full flight simulator. - Three take-offs, approaches and landings in an aeroplane/helicopter or full flight simulator at night. - Hold an IR. - One take-off, approach and landing in an aeroplane/helicopter or full flight simulator at night.

options.text: 1 and 3, 1 and 4, or 2 only
2 and 3 only
2 and 3, 3 and 4
1 and 4 only

variant.question: State the requirement(s) for a familiarisation training:

options.text: Familiarisation training requires the acquisition of additional knowledge.
Familiarisation training requires the acquisition of additional training on the aircraft.
Familiarisation training requires the acquisition of additional knowledge and training on an appropriate training device or the aircraft.
Familiarisation training requires the acquisition of additional training on an appropriate training device or the aircraft.

variant.question: Under which circumstance may the commander grant temporary access to parts of the aircraft, in flight, that are not designed for the accommodation of persons? For the purpose of?

options.text: taking action necessary for the safety of the aircraft or of any person, animal or goods therein.
checking the comfort and well-being of passengers, animals or transported goods.
taking action necessary for the economical operation of the aircraft or the safety and comfort of the flight crew.
ensuring the rest and relaxation of cabin or flight crew during the cruise phase of the flight.

variant.question: Which of the following statements regarding cruise relief co-pilots is false?

options.text: A relief pilot can fly the aircraft as long as it is below FL 200
A relief pilot does not need to be qualified to land or take off
The minimum qualification for a relief pilot is a CPL
A relief pilot requires a type rating on the aircraft

variant.question: On whose authority is access to the Flight Deck granted?

options.text: The Commander.
CAA Inspector.
The relevant Authority.
The Operator.

variant.question: The operator shall take all measures to ensure that no person is in any part of an aircraft in flight that is not designed for the accommodation of persons unless temporary access has been granted by the commander:

options.text: for the purpose of taking action necessary for the safety of the aircraft or of any person, animal or goods therein.
for the purpose to check the health of live animals, to check the safety of goods.
for the purpose to provide more comfort for the flight and cabin crew.
for the purpose of crew relaxing during long haul flights.

variant.question: A person is part of an organisation and wishes to sit on the jumpseat. Is he/she allowed?

options.text: He/She can only occupy a jumpseat if the pilot-in-command permits according to operator procedures.
He/She shall not occupy a jumpseat under any circumstances.
He/She can because he/she is an employee in the same company.
He/She can only if permitted by operator procedures.

variant.question: Facilitation Entry and departure of cargo: ? The production and presentation of the Cargo Manifest and the Air Waybill shall be the responsibility of

options.text: the aircraft operator, or his/her authorised agent.
the aircraft operator, or the owner of the cargo.
the aircraft operator`s authorised agent, or the owner of the cargo.
the aircraft operator`s authorised agent, or the State Customs Officer.

variant.question: You are a newly qualified pilot having recently passed the line check with an established Operator on a multi-pilot aircraft. You arrive in the crew room for your sixth sector / flight with that Operator after training and the line check.  You realise that the Commander is also recently qualified and this is only the third sector / flight that he / she wil fly with the the Operator as Commander. Which statement is correct?

options.text: A maximum of one inexperienced flight crew member is permitted on any flight and enquiries should be made about this crew composition.
The crewing department wil NOT roster two inexperienced crew to fly together and therefore the crew composition will be in accordance with the regulations.
The Commander will be regarded as experienced since it requires many hours of prior flying time in order to qualify to undertake a command course for an Operator.
Any pilot that has completed all training will be considered experienced, so the flight can continue as planned.

variant.question: Which of these must a commander accomplish during a commander's upgrade course? - Engine failure during take-off - Engine failure during cruise - One engine inoperative descent - One engine inoperative landing - One engine inoperative go-around and missed approach
Which of the following is the correct combination for the maximum number of turbo-propelllor types or variants  that a flight crew member can operate,  not within a single licence endorsement.

options.text: three turbo-propellor aeroplane types or variants
two turbo-propellor aeroplane types or variants
one turbo-propellor aeroplane type or variant and one reciprocating engine aeroplane or variant.
one turbo-propellor aeroplane types or variants

variant.question: A crew is performing the last flight of the day, which is a humanitarian aid mission with only cargo on board. Which of the following is correct regarding the security check?

options.text: This must be done before departure to avoid the risk of unlawful interference.
This can be skipped, since the cargo is not expected to be suspicious.
This must be carried out, but does not have to be done until just before arriving, since there are no passengers on board.
This does not need to be done because it is always the decision of the commander if a security check has to be performed or not.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 A flight is planned on a MU2 type propeller aeroplane. During boarding, a cabin crew member notices that a passenger is transporting an antique musket. The passenger says that the firing mechanism has been disable and therefore the weapon cannot be fired. Which of the following options is available to the pilot?

options.text: The musket CANNOT be carried or the type of aeroplane must be changed because sporting weapons CANNOT be carried on the MU2.
Sporting weapons may be stored in the passenger cabin provided they are in a lockable container.
If there is NO ammunition accompanying the musket, it may be transported WITHOUT restrictions.
According to the Operations Manual, a disabled antique weapon is NOT considered a sporting weapon and may therefore be carried in the cabin.

variant.question: How long are crew training records required to be retained?

options.text: 3 years
For the duration of the crew members employment, and the records must be available to a new employer.
7 years
2 years

variant.question: A passenger or crew member has taken onboard unauthorised dangerous goods. The operator shall:

options.text: Report the occurrence without delay to the competent authority and the authority of the State of occurrence
Report the occurrence without delay to the local authority and ATC
Report the occurrence to ICAO and the competent authority
Report the occurrence without delay to the competent authority and ATC

variant.question:
The file kept by an employer on its flight crews records:
1) the training.
2) the test results.
3) a log of flying hours.
4) a summary of the training by reference period.
Which of the following combinations contains all of the correct answers?

options.text: Before the line training.
After the simulator training.
Before the base training.
After the base training.

variant.question: Considering the provisions on flight crew training in the EU Regulation on Air Operations, familiarisation training requires:

options.text: Only the acquisition of additional knowledge.
The acquisition of additional knowledge and training on the aircraft of an appropriate training device.
Refresher training on types currently operated.

variant.question: Where would you find the requirements for the Command upgrade?

options.text: Operations Manual
SOPs
AOC of the Operator
SMS manual

variant.question: During the turnaround and prior to boarding, the flight crew are informed that one of the passengers is an unescorted inadmissible passenger who arrived earlier on the same day on a flight by the same Operator. The person is to be returned to the country where she/he initially travelled from, which is the destination of the flight. Prior to boarding, the flight crew are informed about this. Why?

options.text: A notification is required for any Special Category Passenger (SCP).
The passenger must be restrained upon boarding to prevent disruptive behaviour.
The passenger must travel on a crew seat in the cabin due to lack of a ticket.
The person is classified as a Person of Reduced Mobility (PRM).

variant.question: To act as commander in commercial air transport on a single-pilot aeroplane, how many hours must the holder of a CPL(A) fly on a multi-engine type under IFR?

options.text: 700 h + 400 h PIC
700 h + 200 h PIC
400 h + 100 h PIC
200 h + IR

variant.question: According to OPS regulations, an operator shall not operate an aeroplane carrying at least one passenger, unless at least one cabin crew member is included in the crew, when the maximum approved passenger seating configuration is more than...

A pilot is working for an Operator that has only one aircraft type and variant in their fleet. The Operator is introducing a new aircraft that is considered a common type with the existing fleet, but a different variant to the existing aircraft. What shall the pilot do in order to be able operate on both variants? The pilot:

options.text: Must complete differences training containing both theoretical and practical training.
Must complete familiarisation training including theoretical knowledge training to acquire additional training.
Must complete a type rating on the new variant and afterwards a skill test.
Does NOT require any additional training as both aircraft are considered the same type.

variant.question: A pilot holds a current ATPL(A) that is endorsed with valid class ratings for single engine piston (land) and single engine piston (sea), all flown as single pilot operations. The pilot intends to operate both classes for a Commercial Air Transport Operator. When acting as flight crew for the Operator, the maximum number of aeroplane types or variants that the pilot can operate is:

options.text: Three reciprocating engine aeroplane types or variants.
One reciprocating engine aeroplane type or variant.
Two reciprocating engine aeroplane types or variants.
There is no limit to the number of aeroplane types that the pilots can operate.

variant.question: Flight crew members who operate both helicopters and aeroplanes are limited to operations on..

options.text: only one type of aeroplane and one type of helicopter.
two types of aeroplanes and one type of helicopter.
only one type of aeroplane but there are no limitations on helicopter types.
only one type of helicopter but there are no limitations on aeroplane types.

variant.question:
During a commander's upgrade course, the following must be accomplished:1. Engine failure during take-off. 
 2. Engine failure during cruise. 
 3. One engine inoperative descent. 
 4. One engine inoperative go-around and missed approach. 
 5. One engine inoperative landing.

A technician is about to replace a generator when the PIC arrives to the aircraft. When the commander enters the flight deck and checks the tech log book, he/she realises that this has already been filled and the information is all correct. What should the PIC do?

options.text: The entry in the tech log is not valid, because it has been filled before the work has been finished.
Everything is ok, the tech log is completed, therefore the aircraft is ready to go.
It is enough that the technician comes to the cockpit to verbally confirm that he/she has finished the work.
Ask to engineer to verbally confirm that the replacement has been correctly done.
